awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Dendrite-Suppressing Separator for Next Generation Lithium-ion Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a separator technology that will lead to higher energy density and safer batteries necessary for electric vehicles as well as other applications in industries such as grid energy storage and consumer electronics. Once realized in the commercial world, the proposed approach may significantly advance the current technologies for producing battery cells with a high degree of rate capability, energy density, and safety. The societal benefit is in its ability to accelerate the adoption of electric vehicles and other clean energy solutions by addressing global energy and environmental challenges. Translating the technique to commercial applications may create new jobs and contribute to the improvement of the economy. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a novel battery separator that utilizes a material technique to suppress dendrite formation in fast charging batteries or batteries with lithium metal anodes. The technology may solve the long existing problem of dendrite formation, which causes battery shorting and is a barrier to the commercialization of higher energy, next-generation batteries. This project will help to develop the technique into a commercially ready technology that may accelerate the adoption of high energy density lithium metal batteries as the industry standard. This project will improve understanding of lithium metal batteries and dendrite formation so that new research may focus on further enhancing the performance of lithium metal batteries. This project may have a transformative impact on the translation of separator materials techniques and fundamentals of electrochemistry to battery manufacturing, bridging the technical gap between the fundamental research and commercial production of advanced lithium-ion batteries. The fundamental science and technology associated with dendrite suppression will be further explored to optimize and demonstrate the fabrication technique and products to diverse customers in different formats, sizes and materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
This NSF I-Corps project provided great training experience of two PhD students, working with their mentor, to extend their focus beyond the laboratory to increase the economic and societal impact. The team attended the NSF workshops. Through this workshop the team proposed several business model hypothesis and tested them through the customer discovery process. They interviewed potential customers ranging from small and major Li-ion battery manufactures to automotive industries and equipment suppliers. The team did a systematic literature survey to understand the current manufacturing process, and investigated how their separator can fit in the current manufacturing line without major change of the process. The team also visited battery manufacturers to under how they design, develop and manufacture batteries. Through this I-Corps project, the team formulated a business model and technical path to transition the technique to broader commercialization applications.

Intellectual Merits: Through customer discovery, this project formulates a business model and technical path to push forward a new battery separator technology. This technology will solve the long existing problem of dendrite formation, which is a barrier to the commercialization of higher energy next-generation batteries. This project will have a transformative impact on the translation of separator materials techniques and fundamentals of electrochemistry to lithium-ion battery manufacturing, and therefore bridge the technical gap between the fundamental research and commercial production of advanced Li-ion batteries.


Broader Impacts: The technique to be commercialized in this project will produce high performance batteries that are highly needed by electric vehicles and other applications, which will benefit the society by addressing global energy and environmental challenges. Translating the technique to commercial applications will not only create new jobs and contribute to the improvement of economy, but also increase the US competence in the important area of Li-battery manufacturing.

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2023
Modified by: Wei Lu
